description.summary: Japanese winter spirit depicted as a beautiful woman with pale white skin, long black hair, and white kimono. Appears to travelers in snowstorms and freezes victims with her breath or drains their life force.
description.full: Yuki-Onna, the 'Snow Woman,' is a prominent yokai in Japanese folklore. She appears as a beautiful woman with extremely pale or white skin, long black hair, and wearing a white kimono, materializing during snowstorms. Yuki-Onna encounters travelers in the snow, often leading them astray or directly attacking them with her freezing breath that drains life force. Her behavior varies by regional tradition - sometimes she is purely malevolent, freezing all she meets; other times she shows mercy to those who demonstrate kindness or bravery. The most famous account is Lafcadio Hearn's story in which she spares a young man, warning him never to speak of their encounter, then returns years later as his wife. When he breaks his promise, she vanishes into the snow. Yuki-Onna embodies winter's dual nature: beautiful yet deadly, capable of both mercy and cruelty.

appearance.eyes: Varies - sometimes described as normal, sometimes black or icy blue

features.description: Skin white as snow, sometimes translucent or glowing
Traditional white robes, often indistinguishable from snow
Long, flowing black hair contrasting with pale skin
Leaves no tracks in the snow
Appears and disappears like mist or snow

physical.morphology: Appears as beautiful woman but is fundamentally a spirit of winter. Can materialize and dematerialize at will, especially in snow or blizzards.

abilities.description: Breath that freezes victims solid or drains life force
Control over snow and ice, can create blizzards
Can become invisible during snowstorms, blending with environment
Appears and disappears at will, especially in snowstorms
Can drain vitality from victims, leaving them frozen corpses
Some versions can assume human form convincingly

patterns: Appears to lone travelers in snow
Sometimes merciful to kind or brave individuals
Vengeful if betrayed or promise broken
Vanishes when promise violated or identity revealed

range.description: Throughout Japan, particularly in mountainous and snowy regions

origins.cultural_roots: Japanese yokai tradition, winter folklore, animistic beliefs about nature spirits
origins.earliest_accounts: Muromachi period (1336-1573) oral traditions, formalized in Edo period texts
origins.folklore_connections: Part of broader yokai tradition, connected to nature spirit beliefs

timeline.significance: Early oral traditions of Yuki-Onna emerge
Yuki-Onna stories recorded in yokai compilations
Published definitive Western account in 'Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things'
Masaki Kobayashi's film brings Yuki-Onna to cinema
Modern popular culture adaptation in Pokémon franchise

history.modern_era: Yuki-Onna remains one of the most recognizable yokai in Japanese popular culture. Featured extensively in anime, manga, video games (Pokémon's Froslass), and films. Continues as part of living folklore tradition in Japan.

famous_accounts.name: Lafcadio Hearn's Yuki-Onna
famous_accounts.source: Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things
famous_accounts.description: A woodcutter named Minokichi encounters Yuki-Onna who spares him but warns him never to speak of her. Years later he marries a beautiful woman named O-Yuki who bears his children. When he tells her about his youthful encounter, she reveals herself as Yuki-Onna and vanishes, sparing him only for their children's sake.
famous_accounts.significance: Most famous Western account, established canonical version

symbolism.spiritual_significance: Represents winter as a spirit, embodying both its serene beauty and lethal danger. Symbolizes nature's indifference to human life, capable of mercy or cruelty without pattern.

folklore.beliefs: Yuki-Onna serves as warning against winter travel dangers. Represents real dangers of hypothermia and getting lost in snowstorms personified as a spirit.

literature: Numerous modern manga and light novels
other: Tourism and local festivals in snowy regions

cultural_sensitivity.note: Yuki-Onna is part of traditional Japanese cultural heritage and yokai folklore. While not a religious figure, it represents important cultural beliefs about nature and caution.
guidelines: Recognize as cultural tradition, not mere fiction
Understand folkloric context and warning tale function
Distinguish between traditional folklore and modern adaptations
